author: Staff Reporter
text:
Jewellers put up black flags as a sign of protest against the Centre's proposed excise duty. —Photo: C. Venkatachalapathy

After remaining closed for nine days as part of the nation-wide strike, jewellery shops across the district opened on Monday.

V.S. Ramesh Kumar, secretary of Vellore District Jewellers Association, said they convened an emergency meeting on Monday afternoon to discuss further course of action. Jewellers, pawn brokers, and representatives of corporate companies in Vellore town took part in the meeting.

Human chain

Following the meeting, the members formed a human chain at the Main Bazaar to demand the Central government to withdraw its proposed one per cent excise duty on gold jewellery. About 200 persons took part in the human chain. Shops in the town also put up black flags as a sign of protest.

“After nine days of closure, jewellery shops and pawn broker shops in the town opened on Monday evening. Shops in other parts of the district have opened too,” he said.

There are about 500 jewellers and 3,000 pawn brokers in Vellore district.

He added that members of their Tamil Nadu federation have decided to travel to New Delhi to meet Ministers and Members of Parliament. “About 600 persons from the State will be visiting New Delhi on March 17.

Six members from Vellore will be part of the delegation. We will demand the Central government to roll back the excise duty,” he said.

About 600 members of TN federation will visit New Delhi to urge Centre to roll back excise duty
title: Jewellery shops open after nine-day protest
